Lars,

Ken had some good advice on squaring the fitness (if your raw fitnes=
s
is simply the player's chip stack).  Again, money makes the most sense
as=
 a measure of fitness, especially if you are focused on evolving
come-and-g=
o players in limit Hold 'Em.  If you wanted to focus on
evolving good tourn=
ament players, I'd use rank in a tournament
structure as fitness.

I was th=
inking a bit more about your approach, and to be honest, I
have some reserv=
ations.  Billings and the folks at Univ of Alberta
seem to be using a rule-=
based player, built on a pot-odds player, and
are using neural networks to =
model and predict opponent behavior (if I
understand their approach correct=
ly).

Your approach seems the exact opposite.  You're using rule-based
heur=
istics to model opponents as tight/loose/passive/aggressive, and
seem to be=
 trying to evolve neural networks that have to figure out
things like pot o=
dds on their own.

So I'm wondering what your motivation is for approaching=
 the problem
this way...I have to admit that Billings' approach has greater=

intuitive appeal to me, since figuring things like pot odds are
relatively=
 simple for traditional non-fuzzy programming, and things
like predicting o=
pponent behavior seems like the sort of thing that
you'd want to apply a ne=
uroevolutionary approach to.

Derek
